page.title: 02Ecology; Upton Snodsbury
page.content: In a normally low rainfall area of (approx.24 inches) the countryside in the summer of 1985 is unusually green and lush due to high rainfall throughout the summer. Although all mature elm trees were destroyed by Dutch Elm Disease in the 1970's new elms are being regenerated in the hedgerows. In recent years some hedges were removed to combine small fields making them a more convenient size for large farm implements. The remaining hedges are of mixed species with sycamore, wild rose and quickthorn. A feature of the hedgerows in autumn is the rampant growth of Old Man's Beard (wild clematis) and blackberries in abundance. Fruit trees in the hedgerows - damsons, apples and pears - which are the remains of old orchards, is another feature of the area.
